Posts.Content: Hello I am new to the forum and interested to know if anyone else gets recurring cording after their surgery.  Mine doesn’t seem to go away unless I stretch and move everyday.  I don’t mind this too much except my latest in my belly makes me feel sick, and it’s just a little one.  I am having some fun inventing movements to see if I can heal it......
Posts.Title: Cording after surgery

Posts.Content: Hi I haven’t.  I did all the conventional exercises but I have to say after a while I got a bit bored, so I have made up my own.  I seem to be rather prone to this stringy stuff!  Thanks for getting back to me.  I have had the satisfaction of shifting both the armpit and the rib ones, but the little belly one is harder to move.
Posts.Title: Cording after surgery

Posts.Content: Hello Thank you.  That is good advice.  I am professionally trained but as a yoga teacher, but I learn a lot from other professional perspectives.  A bit of physio advice could be very useful.  I will check her out.
Posts.Title: Cording after surgery

Posts.Content: Hello No! Not a wimp at all.  Let’s see. Mmmmn life threatening disease, major operation, toxic therapies some still ongoing.  In my experience it is a hell of a lot for mind and body to digest and recover from.  My cancer experience started a year ago and I am definitely not right yet, and it is just a few months after radio and chemo.  Still on herceptin and tamoxifen.  It’s all yuck but I am glad to be alive. I couldn’t cope with the FEC-T, I just did seven weeks of taxol before I stopped with neuropathy.  How is that for being a wimp!?  I asked myself the wimp question then. It sounds like you are doing very well.  We are all so different.  Your friend wants you to be well but hasn’t a clue.  Why should she. Pip x
Posts.Title: You must be nearly better now!!! What a whimp!
